Base:Descriptions.Base:Description: $(this.trait:color) $(this.trait:material) harpsichord

A $(this.trait:color) $(this.trait:material) harpsichord. A harpsichord has a lidded rectangular-shaped wooden case, usually comprised of hardwoods, elaborately decorated with intricate carvings and paintings. Inside the case, there are multiple sets of strings that correspond to a particular keyboard to allow the creation of different pitches. The keyboard itself boasts a length of dark wooden keys for naturals and smaller ivory keys for sharps. A set of slender legs support the base of the harpsichord in three places, elevating the main wing-shaped body from the ground. A matching stool rests just before the tier of keyboards, with a music stand situated just above they keys, and before the opening of the lid.

This is a $(this.trait:color) $(this.trait:material) harpsichord, a type of keyboard instrument. Unlike traditional keyboard instruments, this harpsichord has three keyboards, or manuals. The strings are plucked by means of quills or plectrums, instead of struck by small hammers.
harpsichord's ebony keys

Slender ebony keys line the length of the keyboard, alternating with the white keys. Each time one is stuck, the corresponding string within the body of the harpsichord is plucked producing a unique sound.
sharps
harpsichord's ivory keys

Slender white keys line the length of the keyboard, alternating with the black keys. Each time one is stuck, the corresponding string within the body of the harpsichord is plucked producing a unique sound.
three staggered keyboards

Three keyboard manuals that are staggered one above the other, allowing for intricate melodies to be performed directly on top of one another. Black and white keys alternate, providing the opportunity for various harmonies to be played.

Three keyboard manuals that are staggered one above the other, allowing for intricate melodies to be performed directly on top of one another. Black and white keys alternate, providing the opportunity for various harmonies to be played.
harpsichord's keys
Slender keys line the length of the keyboard. Each time one is stuck, the corresponding string within the body of the harpsichord is plucked producing a unique sound.
harpsichord's slender $(this.trait:color) $(this.trait:material) legs
Three legs that can be attached and removed from the base of the body of the instrument, allowing for easy travel.
Three legs that can be attached and removed from the base of the body of the instrument, allowing for easy travel.
intricately painted lid

The wing-shaped lid of the harpsichord, which perfectly covers the internal mechanisms of the instrument. A $(this.trait:painting) painted upon the underside of the lid, only revealed when the lid is propped up.
The wing-shaped lid of the harpsichord, which perfectly covers the internal mechanisms of the instrument.
rectangular $(this.trait:color) $(this.trait:material) music stand
A rectangular $(this.trait:color) $(this.trait:material) stand is positioned centrally above the three manuals, allowing for sheets of music to be displayed for the musician's viewing upon its frame.
A rectangular $(this.trait:color) $(this.trait:material) stand is positioned centrally above the three manuals, allowing for sheets of music to be displayed for the musician's viewing upon its frame.
ornately carved $(this.trait:color) $(this.trait:material) stool
A $(this.trait:color) $(this.trait:material) stool that is placed behind the harpsichord.
A $(this.trait:color) $(this.trait:material) stool that is placed behind the harpsichord.
harpsichord's strings
The strings on a harpsichord which are plucked by means of quills or plectrums.
The strings on a harpsichord which are plucked by means of quills or plectrums.
